questions.text: What is the most powerful activator of sympathetic vasomotor system?

choices.text: Posture of the body against gravity

questions.solution:
The most powerful activator of the sympathetic vasomotor system is CNS ischemic response.

CNS ischemic response:

When blood flow to the vasomotor center in lower brainstem (medulla) is severely decreased, the local concentration of CO2 increases greatly and has a potent effect in stimulating the sympathetic vasomotor nervous control areas in the brain’s medulla. Blood pressure may increase till 250 mmHg. The strong activation may cause some peripheral vessels to occlude.

It doesnt activate till arterial pressure drops to 60mmHg or less, hence it is principally a emergency mechanism.

Note: Baroreceptors are the most common activators, but not the most powerful.

questions.text: During exercise, the organ experiencing the smallest decrease in blood flow is____.
questions.solution:
During exercise, the organ experiencing the smallest decrease in blood flow is brain.

During exercise, the coronary and cerebral systems, are spared of vasoconstrictor effect because both these circulatory areas have poor vasoconstrictor innervation .

questions.text: An elderly man, with congestive cardiac failure, complains of shortness of breath when lying down. What is the mechanism behind this symptom?

choices.text: Reservoir function of veins in lower limbs.

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes orthopnea in congestive heart failure. It is due to reservoir function of pulmonary veins.

Orthopnea is dyspnea occurring in the recumbent position.

It results from redistribution of fluid from the splanchnic circulation and lower extremities (increased venous return) into the heart during recumbency. This increased venous return is not put out by the left ventricle and hence pools in the pulmonary veins that acts as capacitance vessels (reservoir function) adding to the already congested pulmonary vasculature resulting in breathing difficulty.

questions.text: The interstitial fluid pressure is negative in ______.
questions.solution:
The interstitial fluid pressure is negative in the lungs.

The interstitial fluid pressure is slightly negative in the body except in the encapsulated organs.

It is positive in

  • Rigid closed compartments- bone marrow, brain
  • Encapsulated organs - kidney, skeletal muscle

This is due to the fact that in the kidneys, high-pressure vessels push the interstitial fluid against an unyielding fibrous capsule raising the pressure. The same principle applies to skeletal muscle surrounded by layers of fascia.

questions.text: Blood flow per minute in pulmonary circulation is

choices.text: Less than flow through systemic circulation
More than flow through systemic circulation
Equal to flow through systemic circulation

questions.solution:
Blood flow per minute in the pulmonary circulation is equal to flow through the systemic circulation so as to provide continuous blood supply to the body.

If the flow rate is slower in the pulmonary circulation than systemic, then the left ventricle would soon empty completely. If the flow rate is faster in the pulmonary circulation then the left ventricle would be soon overloaded. 

Please note that because some blood flows into the bronchial arteries, the actual flow through the pulmonary circulation is slightly lesser than the flow through the systemic circulation. However, this question aims to state that the blood flow through both pulmonary and systemic circulation is largely equal.

questions.text: A patient was receiving a red cell transfusion following hip arthroplasty. Midway through the transfusion, she developed signs and symptoms of shock. What is the type of shock seen in her?
questions.solution:
The shock due to a transfusion reaction is distributive shock. 

During transfusion reaction, there is decreased systemic vascular resistance due to system-wide vasodilation mediated by release of histamine by mast cells in response to antigen bound IgE, leading to distributive shock.

Types of circulatory shock:

  • Hypovolemic shock: due to decreased blood in vascular compartment. E.g., haemorrhage, dehydration.
  • Cardiogenic shock: due to decreased capacity of heart to pump. E.g., any pathology of heart decreasing its ability to maintain cardiac output.
  • Obstructive shock: due to conditions causing obstruction to blood flow in lungs and heart.E.g:pulmonary embolism.
  • Distributive/vasculogenic shock: excessive vasodilation leading to impaired organ perfusion. E.g: septic shock, SIRS, transfusion reaction, Addisonian crisis, neurogenic shock.

Three stages of shock:

  • Non-progressive: also called compensated shock, where normal compensatory mechanism eventually causes full recovery without help from outside therapy.
  • Progressive: also called non-compensated, without therapy it gets steadily worse.
  • Irreversible: even therapy is inadequate to save life.

questions.text: During foetal life, blood vessel with maximum concentration of oxygen is ___.
questions.solution: During fetal life, blood vessel with maximum concentration of oxygen is umblical vein.

questions.text: Progressive hemorrhagic shock is characterized by ______.

choices.text: Blood clots in the small blood vessels

questions.solution:
Progressive hemorrhagic shock is characterized by the presence of blood clots in the small blood vessels.

The initiating cause of this blockage is sluggish blood flow in the microvessels. Tissue metabolites plus other deterioration products from the ischemic tissues causes minute clots in these vessels. Thus the microvasculature gets blocked by the sludged blood.

In progressive hemorrhagic shock, there is increased lysosomal activity, decreased active transport of sodium and tissue acidosis.

questions.text: The type of shock that has high cardiac output is _________.
questions.solution:
Septic shock is characterized by high cardiac output.

High cardiac output in septic shock is caused by

  • arteriolar dilation in the infected tissues and
  • high metabolic rate and vasodilation (resulting from bacterial toxin stimulating cellular metabolism and from high body temperature).

questions.text: Thin-walled and delicate  vessels like capillaries are less prone to rupture. This can be explained by _______.
questions.solution:
Thin-walled and delicate vessels like capillaries are less prone to rupture and this can be explained by Laplace law.

The principal reason for these vessels' relative invulnerability is their small diameter. The protective effect of small size, in this case, is an example of the law of Laplace.

Laplace law states that tension in the wall of a cylinder (T) is equal to the product of the transmural pressure (P) and the radius (r) divided by the wall thickness (w):

T = Pr/w

As the tissue pressure is low, P is equated to the pressure inside the blood vessel.
W can be ignored as well as capillaries are thin walled. Hence:

P = T/r

In a thin-walled viscus, P = T divided by the two principal radii of curvature of the viscus: P = T (1/r1+1/r2)

In a cylinder such as a blood vessel, one radius is infinite, so P = T /r

Hence, smaller the radius, lower is the tension necessary in the wall to balance the distending pressure.

questions.solution:
The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically in the formula called as Poiseuille's law :

Blood flow (F) inside the vessel depends on: 

  • Pressure difference: directly proportional
  • Viscosity: inversely proportional
  • Radius: directly proportional to the fourth power
  • Length of the vessel: inversely proportional

Here, the radius is doubled so the flow increases by 2 to the power of 4 = 16. 

the length of the vessel is also doubled, so the flow decreases by half (÷2) = 8

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Cuthbertson's metabolic  ebb and flow responses to trauma?

choices.text: The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption.
The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock.
The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion.
The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

questions.solution:
The "flow" phase (not "ebb") leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

Cuthbertson's ebb and flow response to trauma:

The "ebb" phase lasts for a brief duration and is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption, aimed at reducing post traumatic energy depletion.

The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock, which leads to an increased metabolic turnover, activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response. This hypercatabolic condition leads to a significantly increased oxygen consumption and energy expenditure.

In 1942, Cuthbertson was the first to describe distinct phases of the metabolic changes which occur after major trauma. He characterized the "ebb" and the "flow" phases of posttraumatic metabolic alterations.

questions.text: Hering's nerve finally relays in ______.
questions.solution:
The Hering's nerve terminates in the medulla (Tractus solitarius).

Baroreceptor reflexes

  • Carotid baroreceptors → Hering's nerve → the glossopharyngeal nerve → Tractus solitarius in medulla.
  • Aortic baroreceptors → Vagus nerve → tractus solitarius in medulla

questions.text: Microcirculation consists of__________.
questions.solution: Microcirculation consists of capillaries, arterioles , venules and terminal lymphatics.

questions.text: Mayer waves are due to ____.

choices.text: Variation of arterial pressure during each systole.
Variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control of blood pressure
Variation of arterial pressure with changes in respiration.
Variation of arterial pressure with postural change.

questions.solution:
Mayer waves are due to the variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control of blood pressure.

The most important mechanisms are as follows:

I: Baroreceptor and chemoreceptor reflex:

High pressure excites the baroreceptors -->inhibits sympathetic nervous system and lowers the pressure -->The decreased pressure, in turn, reduces the baroreceptor stimulation -->elevating the pressure to a high value (the response is not instantaneous, it is delayed until a few seconds later). This high pressure then initiates another cycle, and the oscillation continues.

II: Oscillation of the CNS Ischemic Response:

The cerebrospinal fluid pressure is raised to 160 mm Hg --> causes compression of cerebral blood vessels --> cerebral ischemia--> CNS ischemic pressure response raises the arterial pressure up to 200mm Hg -->the brain ischemia is relieved and the sympathetic nervous system becomes inactive -->the arterial pressure falls rapidly back to a much lower value, causing brain ischemia once again -->initiates another rise in pressure. This chain of events repeats itself cyclically as long as the cerebrospinal fluid pressure remains elevated.

questions.text: Vasomotion refers to _____.

choices.text: Venous drainage to RA by contraction of IVC.
Intermittent contraction of meta arterioles and precapillary sphincter.
Pulsatile action of arteries which help in lymphatic drainage.
Systolic pumping of  blood by heart in to aorta.

questions.solution:
Vasomotion means intermittent contraction of meta arterioles and precapillary spinchter.

Blood usually does not flow continuously through the capillaries. Instead, it flows intermittently, turning on and off every few seconds or minutes. This is vasomotion, which is responsible for flow of blood in capillaries .

The main regulatory factor for vasomotion is tissue oxygen concentration.

questions.text: Ejection fraction in resting healthy man is approximately___.
questions.solution:
Ejection fraction in resting healthy man is approximately 0.6.

The fraction of the end-diastolic volume that is ejected is called the ejection fraction, usually equal to about 60 %.

questions.text: The relation between ventricular stroke volume and end-diastolic volume is explained by ________
questions.solution:
The relation between ventricular stroke volume and end-diastolic volume is explained by Frank Starling's law.

Length–tension relationship in cardiac muscle is similar to that in skeletal muscle. when the muscle is stretched, the developed tension increases to a maximum and then declines as stretch becomes more extreme. Starling stated that “energy of contraction is proportional to the initial length of the cardiac muscle fibre”. 

When cardiac output is regulated by changes in cardiac fibre length, this is referred to as heterometric regulation.

Conversely, regulation due to changes in contractility independent of length is called homometric regulation.

questions.text: The best index of preload is _______.
questions.solution:
The best index of preload is left ventricular end diastolic volume.

Preload - load that the left ventricle carries before the systole.

Left ventricular end diastolic volume - blood remaining at the end of diastole, which determines stretch of the ventricle and thus force of contraction as explained by frank starlings law.
